awd_titl_txt: Quantifying and Designing for Electrostatic Preorganization in Enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
Enzymes are essential protein molecules that facilitate or catalyze the chemical reactions required for life in all organisms.  With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Anastassia Alexandrova from the University of California, Los Angeles, and Dr. Mark Eberhart from the Colorado School of Mines to investigate how the entirety of the protein molecule, consisting of thousands or even tens of thousands of atoms, creates local electric fields that allow enzymes to function as highly efficient and specific catalysts. This effect at the enzyme's active site, called electrostatic preorganization, is detected through quantum mechanical tools.  The understanding of electrostatic preorganization and the development of these quantum mechanical tools are applied to engineer artificial enzymes with enhanced catalytic functions. The resulting artificial enzymes are potentially important in disease prevention, industrial production of chemicals, and environmental remediation. In addition, the project promotes professional development and training of high school science teachers through an initiative called "See the chemical bond". This initiative uses visual and quantum mechanically enabled techniques in a classroom setting to give substance to the important though often poorly understood concept of chemical bonds.

This proposal develops quantum-mechanically rigorous computational techniques to probe electrostatic preorganization, and assesses its effect on the proficiency of both natural and artificial enzymes. An extension of the Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) in conjunction with dynamics simulations will be developed to determine the perturbative influence of the full protein structure to the charge density (rho) in an enzyme's active site. The directed evolution of artificial enzymes are followed using these probes, while interrogating the progression of preorganization. These studies detect the extent to which enzymes evolve toward improved long-range electrostatics. The insight resulting from these computational investigations allow integration of preorganization into enzyme design by strategically improving electrostatics through remote mutations, with the predictions tested experimentally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Enzymes are biological catalysts, facilitating a variety of biological processes, from photosynthesis to digestion. It is of interest to not only understand how natural enzyme function, but also design new efficient enzymes with new-to-nature functionality. Enzymes are large protein macromolecules, with a small, buried active sites where the catalyzed reaction takes place. It is an outstanding question in biology what the role of the large protein scaffold might be. This program studied the role that intramolecular electric fields, created by charged amino acids placed throughout the protein scaffold, in enzymatic catalysis. Not only would such an understanding promote an appreciation for natural enzymes proficiency and mechanisms, but also would aid enzyme design protocols, which currently omit long-range electrostatic interactions. 

We developed computational tools providing unprecedented insight into the electric fields inside the enzyme active sites. We also developed approaches to analyze and compare these fields, and correlated the electric fields to reactivity, showing that fields indeed tune the reaction mechanisms and rates in several classes of enzymes. Central to our program has been the analysis of the geometry of the electronic density in the active sites. Electron density geometry is exceptionally sensitive to electric fields, and so can report on the fields experienced by the active sites. Electron density also encodes the reactivity, thus serving as a convenient, rigorous, and (importantly) scalar reporter on how the fields affect the reaction barrier. Several classes of natural and artificial enzymes have been studied, including non-metal enzymes such as ketosteroid isomerase and artificial Diels-Alderases, and metalloenzymes such as Fe-heme proteins and Zn-dependent hydrolases, to name a few. Our primary finding is that charge redistribution within atoms (between bonds) that accompanies chemical processes is significant and complimentary to conventional charge density analysis.  Additionally, we have found that there are rigorous, previously unrecognized geometric constraints that limit the redistribution of charge density and other field properties. Furthermore, these tools allow the computation of a host of new geometric and other charge density descriptors that may offer new insight and be useful for machine learning and other statistical modelling.

Broader impacts of this work included contributing to teachers’ educational workshops, providing thousands of students in local schools with material to demonstrate chemical concepts on computers. We developed educational videos, and participated in a public event, Explore Your Universe with a booth. We mentored a diverse group of students and postdocs, and educated them at the important intersection of the fields of biochemistry, physical chemistry, and mathematics. Finally, we took research into classrooms, and developed final projects that resulted in students in the class publishing peer review papers in leading journals. 

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2022
Modified by: Anastassia N Alexandrova
